reviews.author: IW
reviews.comment_content:
Fundamental, Lucy guides us step by step into different concepts. The content is not particularly hard and overlaps with M1 syllabus. For people without M1 background, it might be a bit difficult to catch up at first.

The last few chapters are somewhat similar, so it is important to understand the concept behind each equation.

Syllabus:
-Topic 1 Data description
-Topic 2 Probability
-Topic 3 Random variables
---- non-M1----
Topic 4 Estimation
•  Point estimate, Sampling distribution
•  Confidence intervals
Topic 5 Hypothesis testing
•  One sample, statistically significant?
•  Errors of statistical testing: Type I and Type II errors
•  Two independent samples significantly different?
•  Examining relationships for nominal and ordinal data
Topic 6 Simple Linear regression
•  Basic concept
•  Checking model assumption
•  Prediction and estimation
reviews.comment_teaching:
Lucy is very patient!!
She is open to questions at any moment, in and outside the lecture.
Can explain concepts clearly and will remind us important things to remember.
reviews.comment_grading:
The final exam is quite challenging while quizzes are less demanding.
If you perform well in both quizzes and perform not as well in final, it is still possible to have A range.

Very important: you can use cheat sheet!!!!!

Quiz 20% each, 2 in total
Final 40%
HW 15%
Attendance 5%
reviews.comment_workload:
not particularly high, 3 assignment(group),2 quizzes  and final exam only.

will use iprs to take attendence, not compulsory to attend all lectures. Just pop-quiz with iprs as attendence.

reviews.author: Jc01001
reviews.comment_content: Other people will talk about it, so I do not mention here.
reviews.comment_teaching: Lucy is the best professor I have ever met. Really passionate in teaching. The PowerPoints are clear and helpful. I would highly recommend you take her lecture if ISOM2500 is your required course.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is good in Spring semester. The cut off score are quite low, and the quizzes are manageable in general. The final exam is a bit more challenging but still not terribly difficult. However, the cut off scores of the course are quite high and the grading are bad in Fall Semester according to my friends.

For me:

Homework and Attendance: Almost full mark
Quiz 1: 15/15
Quiz 2: 14/14
Final exam: 42/50
Overall: ~ 93%
Grade: A+

Better than expected as I heard that the A+ cut off was 96% or above in Fall semester.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is quite light, only 3 group assignment in total, each takes around 2 hours if you want to finish it individually.

The only drawback may be the two quizzes. The first quiz is held on early March and the second quiz is held on early April, so they are likely to be your first and last tests you need to take in the midterm period.

reviews.author: sy226
reviews.comment_content: It starts out easy (e.g. mean, median, mode, how to conduct surveys etc) and by the end it's topics that are not too difficult but require a lot of brain power to understand (e.g. linear regression). But it's hard to comment on the content because it's just standard stuff for any beginner statistics class.
reviews.comment_teaching: Jason's accent is classic HK accent. He's really boring and uses too many symbols and abbreviations in his powerpoints. However I appreciate how many examples he uses in his slides, because I can self-learn the content after class in case I fall asleep. He's also very petty about taking attendance and making sure that people don't sign in for others. And he sometimes forgets to pass the attendance sheet around and we all have to stay after class to sign in and risk being late for our next class because of his mistake.
reviews.comment_grading: Most of the grade is from the mid term and final exam, so make sure to study hard. They were noncumulative so if you try hard enough you should do ok. We also had mini quizzes every week that were 3% each (no calculations, all theory and T/F questions.) that force you to come to class. But he is lenient about attendance (somewhat), because you only need to be present for 2/3 of the semester.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is quite light. There are no weekly assignments, but that just means that your grade is mostly from your mid-term and final exam.

reviews.author: clyak
reviews.comment_content:
Module 0. Overview
 Module 1. Data and Variation  
Module 2. Association and Dependence  Module 3. Probability 
Module 4a. Random Variables and Probability Models 
Module 4b. Normal Random Variables 
(Midterm till here)

Module 5. Covariance and Portfolio 
Module 6. Sampling and Sampling Distribution 
Module 7. Standard Error and Confidence Interval 
Module 8. Hypothesis Testing 
Module 9. Fitting Equation to Data 
Module 10. Inference in Simple Linear Regression
(Final till here, non cumulative)

Module 11. ? (There’s a module 11 which is not included in exam but taught. Unfortunately Jason archived everything so I cannot see what that is)
reviews.comment_teaching: A bit boring and he requires attendance every lesson after add-drop period. Try to be on time as once he started the quiz at 9:10 (the lecture starts at 9:00) and only around 15 of us were there lol (he usually starts the quiz at 10:10 sth near the end of the lecture). He caught someone helping the others to take attendance once so try to take your own attendance. He only requires 70% attendance so it’s fine if you skipped one or two lectures.
reviews.comment_grading:
Attendance (70%) --- 10%
Quiz (best 5 out off 7) --- 15%
Midterm (20 MC) --- 25%
Final (40MC) --- 50%

* A 2-sided A4 cheat sheet is allowed in both midterm and final.
(Grading scheme from others, as Jason already archived the course in Canvas)

My statistics:
Attendance 10/10

Quiz around 13/15 (3 full marks; 2 2/3)

Midterm 15/20 (my score is upper quartile, mean should be around 13/20? Not sure)

Final 15/40 (mean around 18/40, highest 32/40. This is unsure but I just tend to see the stats as I woke up at 10 and coincidentally saw the notification of releasing grades and I was quick enough to see my grade. But most probably wishing I’m still in my dreams after seeing this horrifying grade)

My Grade: B

It’s actually a good grade given my horrible final score, as I’m expecting a C- or the best C+ after the glitch release of my final. Jason do give good grades I guess.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload depends on you. If you’re good at maths and understand things quickly, then the workload is extremely low as you just have to copy the formulas in the cheat sheet and apply them on your exams.

For math idiots like me, you have to spend a lot of time to understand the terms and when to use which formula plus fighting with tons of exercises. YouTube might be a good tool for you to understand some knowledge though.

It can be a bit more complicated as you proceed, but simply search the topic on YouTube and you should be fine.
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor's pace is manageable. But sometimes I believe that it's relatively easier to learn online than attending lectures. The professor likes to joke around constantly, and that makes it more interactive and a bit engaging if I may say.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading is acceptable in my opinion.
Make sure to score well in all of your quizzes, cause it's free marks. One more thing, the practice questions for midterm and final exam on Canvas are really really useful, so make sure to go through them!
reviews.comment_workload: Limited workload, except for quizzes, midterm and final exam preparation and self-study.

reviews.author: Vanessa Nguyen
reviews.title: Ok class
reviews.comment_content: Lecture slide is okay. But could be long and confusing at times. Content is the same as any other ISOM2500. Make sure you prepare for the jump in difficulty when she starts talking about hypothesis testing and linear regression if you've never studied it before.
reviews.comment_teaching: Very patient and understanding. Has 5 min break every class and plays music, meanwhile she answers any questions students might have. She probably has the best teaching. She's always willing to answer questions whether that's in class or through email.
reviews.comment_workload: 3 Group Assignments, you can choose your own groupmate, or even work alone.

reviews.author: n1l0h3i0
reviews.title: Contents are easy, but the mark distribution is extremely left-skewed.
reviews.comment_content:
Chapter 1 Data description
 - Recognizing the type of data  
- Using graphs to see the characteristics of data
 - Summarizing messy data into neat numbers

 Chapter 2 Probability
 - Probability
- Random variable, distributions

 Chapter 3 Random variables 
- Discrete random variables: Bernoulli, Binomial distribution
 - Continuous random variables: Uniform, normal distribution, t-distribution

 Chapter 4 Estimation  
- Point estimate, Sampling distribution 
- Confidence intervals

 Chapter 5 Hypothesis testing
 - Errors of statistical testing: Type I and Type II errors 
- Two independent samples significantly different
 - Examining relationships for nominal and ordinal data

 Chapter 6 Simple Linear regression 
- Basic concept - Checking model assumption
 - Prediction and estimation (Confidence interval and prediction interval)

The contents taught are kind of cumulative, you have the understand and familiarize yourself with the prior content to move on to future content. e.g. Confidence interval and hypothesis testing will appear again in simple linear regression.
reviews.comment_teaching:
During lectures, Lucy presented the material in a clear and organized manner, making it easy to understand. She is willing to answer all your questions, such a nice professor.

The atmosphere of the lectures was pleasant, and Lucy gave us a 5-10 minute break to ask questions or rest. During this time, she played music to help us relax.
reviews.comment_grading:
Quiz 1 (20%)

Quiz 2 (20%)

Final (40%)

Homework (16%, each 4%)

Participation (4%)

The quizzes, exam, and homework for Lucy's class are computational-oriented, which is not that hard, to be honest. You may come across some tricky questions but most can be solved using the formulae taught in lessons. Seemingly the grading for Lucy's class will be good. But not really. Because most of the students are able to complete all the tasks without really understanding the content, the mark distribution of all the tasks is extremely left-skewed. If you are a careful person that can minimize the number of stupid mistakes during exams, Lucy is your best choice for ISOM 2500.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload for the course was reasonable, consisting of four assignments that needed to be completed in groups of 3-4 students. Recommend working with groupmates who have strong math skills to ensure success.

There were also two quizzes, covering 2-3 chapters each. The quizzes were of acceptable difficulty, and there was a flexible time limit.

Attendence: 4%
Quiz 1&2: 20% each
Final: 40%

Remember to finish the assignments and submit them very seriously 'cuz thay account for a large proportion of total grade! I failed to submit a few questions in my first assignment and suffered quite a loss.
Suffocating competition, as people in my session nearly get full marks in every test or exam, even assignments. You can find that the quality of giving accurate answers is never more crucial (which is exactly what I lack...).
Kind grading though. It may not be bad but seems rather hard to reach a high level.

My grades:
Full attendence
Assignments: 79, 91~93 (can't remember that clearly), 98, 98
the mean and median are always around 98
Quiz 1: 11/14 mean: 12/14
Quiz 2: 12/13 mean: 12/13
Final: 43/49 mean: 36/49 (I'm not sure if the mean is right)
Finally got a B+, somehow thankful upon seeing this outcome.
reviews.comment_workload:
Definitely light workload, I would say.
Nothing more than 4 assignments, and not too much time required for revision as well.

Statistical inference (involved in quiz 1, very easy)
Normal Distribution (involved in quiz 2, not hard)

reviews.comment_teaching:
First, Prof, Du has a wired accent, which prevents me from understanding in the first few classes, and you will evenutually adapt to it after two weeks. BUT, even you have get used to it, his accent may still distract you from absorbing some important points in his class.
His PPT is abstract and simple, and filled with strange examples that makes it more hard to assess. For example. other prof may use three short paragraphs to illustrate a concept, but Prof. Du only uses three sentences, and you may probably confused after reading 10 times!!! Maybe he isn't so adequate for teaching lol.

Anyway, Prof.DU is VERY responsible. He is very willing to answer our questions with patience. Also, he arranges extra tutorials before each quizes and final, where students can ask their individual questions based on the practice questions on and after the class. That's really helpful.
reviews.comment_grading:
5% Participation
15% Homework
20% quiz 1 (mean 18)
20% quiz 2 (mean 14)
40% final (mean 26)

Final is MUCH MORE DIFFICULT than quizes, so if you do well in quizes but performed badly in final, then your overall may end up tragically too.
reviews.comment_workload:
workload is relatively fine.
Three group homework, hw1 and 2 are easy, 3 is hard because you MUST use excel to tackle with those stupid regression problems.
Also, teaming up with a satisfactory groupmate is very important too! Don't be a freerider!!!

reviews.author: professorwok
reviews.title: friendly professor and good grading
reviews.comment_content:
Part 1 and 2 just cover M1 stuff, Part 3 needs more revision. The content is actually very easy as its mainly understanding concept and applying the formulas, no proofs or anything crazy.

Optional Reading Material: Statistics for Business: Decision Making and Analysis by Foster and Stine.

Part 1.
One Variable Statistics
Two Variable Statistics
Probability and Conditional Probability (include Bayes Theorem)
Discrete Random Variables and Association between Random Variables (include stock portfolio application)

Part 2.
Normal Random Variable (Include standardization)
Sampling Distribution (mainly mean and proportion)
Confidence Interval

Part 3.
Hypothesis Testing (Null and Alternative Hypothesis)
Linear Regression and Transformation
Regression Model and Regression Diagnosis
reviews.comment_teaching:
Friendly professor with unlimited patience, willing to repeat himself and answer even the simplest of questions. His accent is not as bad as the others say. However he sometimes goes a bit slow.

Professor also create his own ppt which are very useful (Many concept question use ppt wording). Past paper question banks contain 2.5x the actual exam amount.

TA prepares tutorials on excel to do homework assignments and also revision sessions before an exam.

At the end of each part, there are game sessions to test the statistics theories we learnt in class.
Part 1 game was about rolling dice to simulate investment outcome
Part 2 game was about testing the proportion of specific coloured M&Ms in a packet.
reviews.comment_grading:
All exam are non-cumulative and allow two sided A4 cheat sheet.

1. 2x Midterms (each 20%). 1 hour, and 20 MC, covers Part 1 and Part 2.
MT 1. Mean: 17.96, SD 2.1
MT 2. Mean: 15.14, SD 2.98

2. Final (40%) 2 hours, 40 MC, covers Part 3
Mean: 26.74, SD 7.7

3. 3x Homework assignment (each 5%). Can work in groups of three. Each assignment covers one part.

4. Attendance (5%): Randomly pick 5-6 lectures for attendance, if you attend at least 5 you get full marks. My recommendation: attend all lectures!
reviews.comment_workload:
Only 3 group assignments for the whole semesters. To practice for exams, just redo past papers multiple times. For the first two parts, the past paper is very similar to the actual exam, but for the final its very different, so you need to really understand the concepts.

Also, even though the exams are non-cumulative, the later content cover the earlier parts, so it is important you don't fall behind.

reviews.author: Yinslash

Probability

If you want to aim high for this course, strongly recommend you to prepare for future topics asap as it does take time to understand the topic and drill deep.
reviews.comment_teaching:
TBH, HIS ENLGISH ACCENT IS NOT THAT GOOD, marginally better than math professor...
But he is willing to teach you after class, and his passion for teaching could be seen as well. If you willing to aim high, don't hesitate and ask professor questions.
During class, he uses different methods to make the teaching as interactive as possible (although tbh no one would like to answer questions online as it does not count on attendance...), such as playing video and ask questions.
reviews.comment_grading:

Quiz 1: 18/20 (Mean 14.4 SD 3.6)

reviews.comment_workload: Workload is average compare with other courses like FINA. Only two group assignments need to be done. However, to aim high score, hard work will be needed for preparing both the quizzes, as well as doing the best possible for assignments.

reviews.author: Pepi
reviews.title: Course with lengthy content
reviews.comment_content:
The content was actually very well organized as compared with other classes. Lecturer goes very systematically according to her slides and the textbook is well-aligned with class content.

However, there is a lack of exercise given by lecturer in class which makes practice for complicated contents inadequate.
reviews.comment_teaching: The teaching style of professor is very orderly. There is always an explanation to every line in the notes and the professor will not skip any parts and always ensure his students pay attention in lessons. His major pet peeve is using the mobile phone in class.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading is really bad for as the mean for every examination is really high. The assignments are all expected to score 100% in order to secure a better grade.

I obtained a 87 in my final grade and it was a B so you can imagine the mean.
reviews.comment_workload: Workload is acceptable. There is little/ no class exercises but assignments are okay if you are doing it with your groupmates. Acceptable workload, overall.

reviews.comment_grading:

attendance 5/5
assignments 15/15
quiz 1 16/20
quiz 2  20/20
final exam 30/40
overall 86/100, ended up with an A-

reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is light. During the semester, we have had
- Three assignments (which could be finished as a group or individually)
- Two quizzes (I would say the questions were fundamental and highly similar to the practice questions given before the quiz)
- Final exam (the hardest one throughout the course)
I did spend hours reviewing the recordings and doing the practice questions before the exam as I was distracted during the zoom lesson. If you average the workload on daily basis, it is not much.

reviews.author: KTSK26
reviews.title: ナイス！！
reviews.comment_content:
It was actually based on the textbook 'Statistics for Business: Pearson New International Edition: Decision Making and Analysis' by R. L. Stine, Dean Foster
Just type in
Statistics for Business: Pearson New International Edition PDF EBook : Decision Making and Analysis
at My UST Services Library Gateway and search,
you can read the whole book online.
Of course, you can purchase the ebook and read it in the 'Bookshelf' app too.
Professor Kawaguchi would not give you answers to the end-of-chapter exercises, but you could ask him/Stacey (TA) if you really got stuck or unsure. You may also find some answers at the end of the chapter of the textbook or through Google searches www
Link to download solution manual sample: https://downloadusb.com/p/solutions-manual-for-statistics-for-business-decision-making-and-analysis-3rd-edition-by-stine-ibsn-9780134508672/
Remember to read the textbook and follow Professor Kawaguchi's advice to finish the end-of-chapter exercises!

Coverage:
1. Introduction
2. Data
3. Describing Categorical Data
4. Describing Numerical Data
5. Association between Categorical Variables
6. Association between Quantitative Variables
7. Probability
8. Conditional Probability
9. Random Variables
10. Association between Random Variables
11. Probability Models for Counts
12. The Normal Probability Model
13. Samples and Surveys
14. Sampling Variation and Quality
15. Confidence Intervals
16. Statistical Tests
17. Comparison
18. Inference for Counts
19. Linear Patterns
20. Curved Patterns
21. The Simple Regression Model
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Kawaguchi is a super nice prof who would answer your questions and explain the concepts until you understand. You can easily reach him/Stacey through the Slack workspace he opened for the class. His approachable and humble character makes the class atmosphere lively!
He gave mock mid-terms and finals for us to practice the MCQs. Those exercise tests have explanations and answers so make sure you go through them at least once before the tests! (some MCQs (roughly 3-4 per test) are copied from the mock test 😏)
One thing to note is that Professor Kawaguchi's Japanese accent was quite strong, it could take about 3-4 lessons to have a better grasp of what he is saying... so make sure you know some Japanese (hiragana lol) and note the way how he pronounces some common words to help yourself follow his useful and chill teaching. For example...

Putting stress on the second syllable:
paTURN -> pattern
moDALE -> model

'k' -> 'c'
suKAra -> scalar

'sym'/'s' -> 'shi'
shimbol -> symbol
shimmatric -> symmetric
shingulu -> single

'age' -> 'ji'
pAsentaji -> percentage  

'r' -> 'l'
rike -> like
onrine -> online
raptop -> laptop
recture -> lecture
raBEL -> level

'f' -> 'v' and 'th'
falue -> value
fariable -> variable
freshold -> threshold

Typical ones:
klum -> column
huust -> host
ofun -> often
je-score -> z-score
pikus -> peaks
Gugu -> Google
bugu -> bag
wrist -> list
aahfarege -> average

I don't mean to tease Professor Kawaguchi's accent. I only hope to list some examples here to illustrate there were patterns in his pronunciation. After taking some time to understand, you would find his lectures even more enjoyable. I really like his structured and rich teaching! 😄
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is absolute, so there is no need to be afraid about your competitive peers getting the curve over the ceiling.

No participation marks, but I really encourage you to attend physical live lectures since it was a bit difficult to catch what the professor was saying in the Zoom recordings. He also liked drawing important graphs and writing examples on the classroom whiteboard. You could not really see them clearly in the recordings.

Some stats for reference (my classmates were geniuses😂)

Mid-term Quiz 1: (Full mark: 20)
Mean: 17.316
StDev: 2.091
Min: 9.0
Median: 18.0
Max: 20.0

Mid-term Quiz 2: (Full mark: 20)
Mean: 18.338
StDev: 1.991
Median: 19.0
Max: 20.0

Final: (Full mark: 40)
Mean: 28.897
StDev: 5.925
Median: 30.0
Max: 39.0
reviews.comment_workload:
Very easy Assignments mostly with video tutorials after every lecture, about once a week.
You only need to hand in 7 out of 19 in my memory (Professor Kawaguchi often repeated this requirement so you would definitely know)
They are great for revision and understanding so please try your best to complete and submit them weekly:]

2 Mid-term Quizzes:
Each with about 20 MCQs. Manageable once you finish all the assigned end-of-chapter questions diligently.

1 Final:
With 40 MCQs. Suddenly got much more difficult than the previous tests with the last chapters. Please spend more time understanding and mastering the difficult content.

reviews.author: blue :)
reviews.comment_content:
8 Chapters in total:
- Descriptive statistics
- Probability concepts, random variables, and expected values
- Binomial distribution
- Normal distribution
- Sampling distribution
- Confidence interval estimation
- Hypothesis testing
- Correlation and regression analysis

The first half of the course is easy but the second half of the course (Hypothesis testing & Correlation and regression analysis) is highly challenging.

The situation was even worse since we had to learn the whole last chapter in a week because there wasn't enough time for Mr. Mike So to finish teaching all the contents. This made us really struggle in the course of preparation for the finals.
reviews.comment_teaching: Mr. Mike So is a passionate professor. The teaching pace is fast but you can rewatch the zoom recording afterward if you cannot catch up in class. He also walked us through lots of real-life applications of statistical knowledge which I think is beneficial to our learning. He is patient and is willing to answer all your questions after class. Overall, his teaching is okay but his attitude is great.
reviews.comment_grading:
Coursework: 20% (3 group assignments in total)
Quiz 1: 20% (20 MCQ, 1 mark each)
Quiz 2: 20% (20 MCQ, 1 mark each)
Final examination: 40% (40 MCQ, 1 mark each)

Coursework/ Assignments are related to the topic you learned in class but require excel skills. TA would explain how to solve similar types of questions using excel in the tutorial session, so make sure you don't miss the lecture.

Quizzes and Finals are MCQ.
The quizzes are easy but the final exam is really hard. I got 1 mark above mean for both quizzes, while my assignment grades are below mean. The final exam grade was not released but I reckon I did really bad in finals (I thought I would fail this course). Out of my expectation, the final grade is B+ which is okay for me since I can feel my final exam is a disaster.
reviews.comment_workload:
Medium.

There are only 3 assignments throughout the semester. The first two are relatively easy while the last one might take up lots of your time.

The quizzes and final exam are open-book. Just make sure you did lots of practice questions beforehand then you will be fine :)

reviews.author: NoNeedToKnow
reviews.title: Good Grade + Good professor
reviews.comment_content:
Same as what other people said.
If you have studied DSE M1 or probability in high school, there is an advantage that literally you can skip the first 5 chapters. For me the most difficult part is linear regression (Ch.8) but alas, due to insufficient time (i.e. less than 2 weeks) for teaching the last chapter before the final, I didn't have enough time to assimilate the concepts and ideas. I would suggest pre-studying the last chapter yourself.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor SO is a good teacher who really explains everything clearly in detail. I like how he incorporates daily examples such as phenomenon in the stock market to explain the concepts and ideas. He is very willing to answer you questions and for local students you could ask him in canto as well. He is also quite lenient in terms of grading. The only thing is I could not find much pp or exercises from this professor so I just did pp and exercises by other professors.
reviews.comment_grading:
GOOD GRADE.
I mean I didn't get A range but given the fact that I didn't revise for the final (and yes I even forgot the date of the exam and I only did a quick revision in the morning 3 hours before the exam) and still got B+ is really surprising for me. Tbh, even during the exam, I still didn't fully understand the concepts of linear regression but unfortunately there is a great proportion of questions that are testing your knowledge in linear regression.

Assignment 1 13/13
Assignment 2 11/11
Assignment 3 26/28
Quiz 1 16/20
Quiz 2 19/20
Final exam -/40 (probably around 25 I guess)
All quizzes and exams (in form of MCs) are allowed to open-book but I don't think this would benefit you much even though this is the sole reason why I didn't revise much before the exam.
reviews.comment_workload:
LOW WORKLOAD ( 3 assignments in form of group work + 2 quizzes + final)
But bear in mind Excel skills like plotting graphs are required in order to complete the assignments. As a person who lacks excel skills, I need to self-learn how to use excel myself as personally I don't find the tutorials about excel is useful at all.

reviews.author: Rrrrr
reviews.comment_content:
Syllabus:
- Data and variation.
- Time series data.
- Transform data.
- Probability and its rules.
- Tools for organizing probability.
- Probability models.

- Association and dependence.

reviews.comment_teaching: Not bad tho he has a typcial Chinese accent. But it became better when you were familiar with his accent
reviews.comment_grading: I got 88/100 and the grade was A. It consists of 3 assignments, 2 quizzes and 1 final. I averagely had 1.5 sd above mean.
reviews.comment_workload: Not too heavy

reviews.author: Leocyh
reviews.title: Easy course
reviews.comment_content: It is easy. Some of the knowledge has been taught in secondary school. Such as Mean, Range, Max, Low, s.d., variance. If you remember all of them, it will be an easy course for you.
reviews.comment_teaching: Nice teaching. And all knowledge can be found in the PowerPoint.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading is good. Just slightly higher than the mean may get an A range. The exam and the quizzes are easy too.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is okay. Just a few assignments. And don't need a lot of time to revise.

reviews.author: Wolfie
reviews.title: Good grade but slightly confusing
reviews.comment_content:
Overall content is quite simple - does not require much math background to do well in this course.

The more advanced concepts doesn't require much calculation, more emphasis was instead placed on understanding the concept itself instead of actual problem solving.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof. James uses powerpoint to teach - though the quality of the class materials vary and so does the source.

A challenge I faced during the time I spent taking the class was keeping up with lecture content as he often times jumped between different topics and also between his virtual whiteboard and the powerpoint itself.

Points I have made about the content are true assuming that you know what is within scope and what isn't - which is quite hard to gauge. I personally emailed Prof. James and the TA quite often in order to clairfy.
reviews.comment_grading:
Assessments include mid-term and final exams, quizzes and assignments. Participation marks are gained through being present in lectures. Prof. James is very friendly and engaging in class with him is both fun and helps out in the long run.

I would say grading is fair and follows the SBM expectations. I think scoring mean results in a B.

Personally, I scored 1 and 1.5 SD's above mean in the Mid-term and Final exams respectively - got an A grade in the end.
reviews.comment_workload:
Workload is very fair but doing well in the assessments requires alot of revision as the material isn't very complex or difficult.

Again, clearing up any confusion with regards to scope and concepts early on will definitely help. The TA and Prof. James are very helpful and responsive through email.

reviews.comment_content:
Total 8 chapters.

reviews.comment_teaching:
A little boring.
He often makes simple things sound complicated. If I had not studied M1 in secondary school, I would have thought that chapters 1 to 6 would be very difficult to understand and apply.


Not every class has recording. Only the classes which held in add/drop period and related to Ch 8 (the most difficult chapter) have recordings.

Two tutorials to teach you how to use Excel, but the TA was not very familiar with using Excel in Macbook.

reviews.author: MovieTeddy
reviews.title: For people who do not want a difficult syllabus and prefer minimal workload
reviews.comment_content:
I agree that this syllabus gives students who studied M1 an advantage in terms of workload, as topics such as probability, normal distribution, and confidence intervals, as they have already learned it.
However, the syllabus of the whole course for this Professor is relatively the easiest and shortest when compared to other professors in this semester, as it did not drill deep into more difficult topics such as the Simple Regression Model.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Kohei has a very heavy Japanese accent, and it can be difficult to catch his words in face-to-face lessons and even harder in zoom recordings. I think his explanations are quite clear for people with or without M1. His PowerPoint slides are mainly a summary from the book, so you can understand the course content by referring back to the book or search for videos on YouTube. However, sometimes he spent a lot of time talking about the proof of equations and rationale behind it, so his teaching speed is overall rather slow.
He also uses a software called "Slack" to communicate with his students and release course and exam materials. We can reach out to him and TA for any questions easily, which is very convenient.
reviews.comment_grading:
The syllabus for each quiz is not too much. All quizzes are said to be cumulative, but in fact, there are not many questions on the tested chapters. For the two quizzes, they are comparatively easy as they are very similar to the sample paper they provided. So, the mean and median for each quiz are very high, and getting one MC wrong can cost you a lot. The final is relatively more difficult, so I would say the score of your finals can make a HUGE difference in terms of your final grade. I suggest getting sources (e.g. question bank) to prepare for exams, as there is a large chance the same question type would appear in the quizzes and exams

Grading method:
Quiz 1 (15%): Mean 17.316  SD 2.091 Median 18 Max 20 (Total 20 MCQ)
Quiz 2 (15%): Mean 18.338, SD 2.8 Median 19 Max 20 (Total 20 MCQ)
Final (40%): Mean 28.897, SD 5.925 Max 39
HWx6 (30%) (5% each)
*NO attendance mark

For reference only:
Quiz 1 20 Quiz 2 19 Final 37 HW 30
Overall mark: 96.25%
Letter grade: A+
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is VERY low. In around 20 pieces of HW he gave after the end of each chapter, only 6 pieces are counted. As long as you score a full mark in 6 of the HW he gave out, you can already guarantee 30% of your course. Attendance is not counted and zoom recordings are provided. There are only two quizzes and one final in total.

reviews.author: wenwen
reviews.title: Don’t know what’s happening…
reviews.comment_content: Basic but very important concepts and a foundational isom class. He taught how to use excel in class most of times, but they are not required in exams… maybe useful in the workplaces
reviews.comment_teaching: Japanese teacher… cannot understand his accent, although He tried very hard to illustrate. He is a patient teacher and will answer ur question in chat box. Still, accent is horrible…
reviews.comment_grading: Normal cuz I can’t understand what he’s sayin… luckily midterm and final are MCs and I got around mean scores. So B range!!
reviews.comment_workload: No assignment as I recalled, only a midterm and a final exam

reviews.author: BusyBee
reviews.comment_content:
If you did IB Math AI HL, this course is very similar (especially the first few topics)!

This course includes probability, hypoth testing, regression, etc. But not to worry it does not go in too deep, and the professor makes it very clear what we actually need to know and what will be tested.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor DU, Lilun is really nice and helpful. He is also funny and tries to make lessons interesting and engaging. He always gives us a break in the middle of the class, to ensure we don't burn out.

For one of the "game" lessons, he even gave us M&M candies to visually illustrate one of the probability ideas taught earlier on.

After class or during office hours, you can find him and he's extremely helpful when explaining a concept or answering your questions.

Overall, I really enjoyed his classes.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grade Composition:

Attendance: 5% (by iPRS)
Assignments: 15%
Quiz 1: 20%
Quiz 2: 20%
Final Exam: 40%

Prof Lilun Du is smart, as he will randomly take attendance so that students can't "prepare" and only attend lectures on those days. My advice—attend them all.

As for the assignments (3 in total), we were given an option to do them alone or form groups. Either way, they're not too bad as each one only has a few questions (around 6 to 7) and should be manageable if you paid attention in lectures.

Quiz 1, Quiz 2 and Finals are all MC exams, with the quizzes being 20 questions each while the final exam has 40. Quiz 1 and 2 were extremely easy, while finals are a bit more challenging. A one-page A4 cheat sheet is allowed for all these assessments.

I think this course has fair grading.
reviews.comment_workload:
I personally think the workload is extremely manageable if you do things in a timely manner and don't keep pushing things to the future. Plus, the first two quizzes (Quiz 1 + Quiz 2) are quite easy and very similar to the practice quiz he hands out for our preparation. He even threw in some exact questions from the practice set in those quizzes!

My advice is—as long as you follow the pace of the lectures and do the recommended work, you'll be fine in this course!

reviews.author: Essssssssss
reviews.title: Good teaching, but hard to get high score
reviews.comment_content:
The professor is really passionate about teaching the contents to students. She carefully listens to the feedback or questions from the students. But the thing is that the content itself is quite hard for year 1 students to fully understand, but maybe it depends. Personally,  I didn't have any background knowledge about statistics and ended up getting a really bad score. But the professor is really nice and passionate!

The progress of the lecture is quite fast as well. Try to catch up on everything before new content starts.

The attendance is checked as well; I remember you are able to absent for 1-2 times.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Passionate.
Listen to students.
Listen to feedback & questions.
Prompt reply to emails.
reviews.comment_grading:
Not bad; reasonable.
If you have a piece of background knowledge about statistics, then everything would be fine. But personally, I didn't have any knowledge about it and ended up getting a bad score. But the grading itself it quite reasonable.
reviews.comment_workload:
2-3 group assignments - professor chooses the group members. (4 members)
Group discussions during the lecture; mine was as breakout rooms during zoom meetings.
Mid-term & Final Exam (Online semester, both of them were multiple choices questions.) - not easy at all.

reviews.author: TLHW
reviews.title: Better to learn from YouTube
reviews.comment_content:
This course is all about mathematical statistics and how they will be applied to business cases. Local students with M1 backgrounds could gain advantages but if not, it won't be a problem. (I am not a M1 student too)
However, in order to have a better understanding of particular topics and math skills, I do recommend watching tutorial videos on Youtube and You will have an explosion of mind then.

reviews.comment_teaching:
He is Japanese and don't expect you can get all his points from the lecture due to his accent. However, this professor is kind and helpful for sure. He will take care of each student if they have questions in class or after class. Don't hesitate to make appointments with him to talk or ask.
One thing to remind: Avoid attending his class via zoom as his audio will be more terrible than in person
reviews.comment_grading:
For this instructor, he used absolute grading.
Approximately A range for >= 90, B range for >= 80, and C range for >= 50
Regarding the assignment (30%):
Each lecture will have assignments but only the best 6 of them will be counted into grading. Questions in assignments include excel (just follow the step from the lecture slide) and textbook exercises.

Regarding the two midterms (30%, 15% each):
1.5hr, 20 MC for each, just practice the textbook exercises to get prepared

Regarding the Final Exam (40%):
1.5hr, 40MC. The only thing to mention perhaps will be time management!!! Don't use the mindset of Midterm to conduct the final exam since the number of questions is doubled with the same time limit.

The grade for me is fair as it is absolute grading
Asm: 100%
Midterm 1: 18/20
Midterm 2: 19/20
Final Exam: 31/40 (Mean: 28.9/40)

Grade: B+
reviews.comment_workload: As this professor didn't assign any group project, presentation, the workload is reasonable

reviews.author: M&A
reviews.comment_content:
Mostly basic knowledge about statistics. If you studied M1 in HKDSE, then you should find most of the content easy. The only new thing would be hypothesis testing and linear regression. However, for M2 students like me, it might take some time to understand some concepts. I personally found it hard to study for this course, maybe my IQ was too low to comprehend the content.
For more details, please refer to others' reviews.
reviews.comment_teaching:
I found it extremely hard to understand what Prof Du said due to his interesting accent. I know that he was passionate, but I just wasn't able to pay attention to what he said. And again, maybe I was too stupid to understand.
However, what I like about his teaching was that he gave us practice exercises and organized tutorial sessions before every mid-term & the final exam. If you encounter difficulty when you do those practice questions, you may ask him during the tutorial session. What's more, some of the practice questions would appear in the mid-term exams/final exam, so if you familiarize yourself with the practice questions, you can secure a portion of marks in the exams.
The TA is helpful and would reply to emails quite quickly.
reviews.comment_grading:
Mid-term I: 20% (20 mc questions, 1 mark each)
Mid-term II: 20% (20 mc questions, 1 mark each)
Final exam: 40% (40 mc questions , 1 mark each)
Assignments: 15% (3 in total, 5% each)
Attendance: 5% (5 times, randomly chosen, 1% each)
My scores:
Mid-term I: 20/20 (mean:16.2, highest:20)
Mid-term II: 19/20 (mean:15.7, highest:20)
Final exam: 30/40 (mean: 23.2, highest:37)
Assignments: 14.9
Attendance: full
Total: 88.9/100
I thought I would only get a B+ or A- but I eventually got an A. Prof. Du is super lenient.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload mainly comes from the 3 assignments. You can either do it in groups or finish it individually, it's up to you. Each assignment consists of an average of 7 questions, and around 3-4 questions require the use of excel. If you are not good at tech, I highly suggest that you find groupmates, or else it would take you a lot of time to finish them and you would feel frustrated.
In addition to that, I personally spent a lot of time reading the textbook and doing the practice exercises over and over again as my IQ probably wasn't high enough to understand the stat concepts, especially hypothesis testing and linear regression. If you are smart enough, you may spend much less time on doing revision, and your workload would only be those assignments.

reviews.comment_teaching: Prof and TA are both really kind and helpful. Prof DU tried his best to make this course interesting. His accent is cute, which may confuse you at first but you will enjoy it later hahhh. TA YIN is very considerate and warmhearted. If you have qustions, you can contact them freely. Evaluation:
1. Midterm 40%: there will be two quizzes testing Part I (20%) and Part II (20%)
respectively. All questions in exams are multiple-choice ones.
2. Final Exam 40%: covers Part III, which will also be multiple-choice format.

reviews.author: Jimmy_ICF
reviews.title: Du Lilun is the best prof
reviews.comment_content:
The course is just about some basic statistic knowledge and it is not very difficult. I have taken the Edexcel GCE A level exams and the topic covered in this course is quite similar to what is taught in S1~S3. If you have studied A level during high school, studying this course should be a cakewalk for you.

Prof. Du actually make his own PowerPoints and the content in the ppt is not the same as the content covered in the textbook. Some chapters in the textbook is not taught in the course, such as binomial distribution. Therefore, the textbook is not necessary.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof. Du is the best professor, period. His accent may be a bit hard to understand when you first hear it, but you'll get used to it in no time. Aside from his accent, his teaching is flawless. He makes his own PowerPoints so you don't need to waste a few hundreds on buying the textbook. His explanations are very clearly and concise. He is even better than some of my high school teachers!

Most importantly, he will upload exercise onto canvas before every exams. You can practice and get an idea of what types of question will appear in the test. He will also hold a tutorial before each exams so you can ask questions if you don't understand the course material.

Swapping to his lecture is one of the best decision I've ever made. He is an angel sent by god to save students.
reviews.comment_grading:
Midterms:40%
Final Exam:40%
Assignments:15%
Attendance:5%

1st midterm: Mean 16.6/20 SD 2.6 (highest 20)
2nd midterm: Mean 15.7/20 SD 2.8 (highest 20)
Final exam: Mean 23.2/40 SD 6.8 (highest 37)

I get 20 in the 1st midterm, 19 in the 2nd one and 37 in the final exam. For the 3 assignments and I get an average of 99.33. Attendance is easy marks so I get all 5%. Final score is 95.9 with the highest being 96.9.
Letter grade A+

Here are some tips to get good grade:
1. For both midterms, remember to do the exercises given by Prof. Du. Redo them for a few times to make sure you understand all the content.
2. Review the ppts before exam. Make sure you understand all of the content taught during lecture. Some terms are kind of confusing so be careful when doing revision. For instance, sample and population.
3. Both midterms and the final exam are multiple choice so the overall difficulty is not too high,
4. Assignment is a groupwork so it is easy to get high mark. However, you can choose to not join any group and do it by yourself. There are just 7 or 8 questions per assignment so it's not difficult even if you don't have teammates. Just pay attention to the details in question, as some questions are quite tricky. If you have problems, just ask the TA or the prof. Try to score as high as you can.
5. Prof. Du only take attendance in 5 lectures and he will usually tell you in advance. Easy marks.
6. Although the 2 midterms is really easy(even homework is harder than midterms), the final exam is incredibly difficult. Just doing the exercises is far from enough. You need to have perfect understanding of everything taught in class, especially the part about Regression diagnosis. EVERY DETAIL IS IMPORTANT. EVERY SENTENCE IN THE PPT IS CRUCIAL. Review the lecture recording for at least once.
7. Cheat sheet(A4 size) is allowed in the midterms and final exam. Besides from formula, copying definition of some confusing terms can be helpful too.

It is extremely hard to get A+ as only the top 2~3% can get an A+, which means that only 4~6 students can get A+. I think you need to score around 95 to get an A+.

Getting in A range is not hard though, as the midterms and assignment is easy. Just put in effort and you can get a good grade. Effort always pay off.
reviews.comment_workload:
The 3 assignments is groupwork so it's easy to finish it. An hour or two should be enough for each assignment.
Revision for midterms and exam is not very time consuming so the workload is quite light.

reviews.title: Good professor with detailed explanation of the concepts
reviews.comment_content:
1. Descriptive Statistics

reviews.comment_teaching: I would say he is experienced in teaching new and hard concepts to someone who has never trained and touched with statistics. He explained difficult concepts step by step and would not introduce the formula at the beginning. He is like telling a story to you by using a lot of real life examples and he often explains the intuition behind the operation which makes the formula understandable and we know why we have that concept. Also, he makes use of the whiteboard in his ipad which he writes everything down on it and it is good for you to write it down because it helps you enhance your understanding. However, there are some times when the screen display of the ipad has some connection problems. But it's not a big problem and it doesn't affect his teaching at all. All in all, his teaching is like explaining concepts to his clients without any statistical background which is suitable for people without M1 background. I really enjoy his teaching a lot as he always includes real life examples at the end of some chapters. Good professor!
reviews.comment_grading:
Assignments: 20% (there are three assignments and two of them involves the use of excel to solve problems. You will know how to use excel because there will be tutorial on using excel)
First assignment: 12/13 (mean:11.9, high:13)

All quizzes and final are MC but he will test a lot of concepts, not just calculations so make sure you have to grasp the concepts clearly.

reviews.author: Smashgod
reviews.comment_content:
Syllabus for Fall 2021-2022:
1 Introduction Ch.1  
2 Data  Ch.2  
3 Describing categorical data  Ch.3  
4 Describing numerical data  Ch.4  
5 Association between categorical variables  Ch.5  
6 Association between quantitative variables  Ch.6  
7 Probability  Ch.7  
8 Conditional probability  Ch. 8
9 Random variables  Ch.9
10 Association between random variables  Ch.10  
11 Probability models for counts  Ch.11  
12 The normal probability model  Ch.12  
13 Samples and surveys  Ch.13  
14 Sampling variation and quality  Ch.14  
15 Confidence intervals Ch.15  
16 Statistical tests  Ch.16
19 Linear patterns Ch.19  
20 Curved patterns Ch.20
21 The simple regression model  Ch.21

Most concepts from Ch.1-8 have been covered in high school subjects such as Mathematics. Starting from Ch.9, there will be a considerable number of equations and formulas introduced, as well as new (and abstract) concepts. Starting from Ch.15, it gets the hardest and the concepts are difficult to understand thoroughly. 1 lesson per chapter on average.

The textbook can be accessed for free online. There is no need to purchase a new one since it is not compulsory.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Mr. Kawaguchi has a Japanese accent when teaching but it didn't take us very long to get used to it. Since the keywords are on the PowerPoint, we usually know what he is referring to and talking about.

He will do a review before the mid-term and final exams. There is usually a sample mock paper (not a compulsory assignment) provided the week before, and the lesson before the exam will be used to check it.

Mr. Kawaguchi and the syllabus say that attendance is compulsory but he never actually takes the attendance. I see some people being absent but the attendance rate for his classes is usually high.

We also use a platform called 'Slack workspace' (similar to Discord but we don't use it for calls) for asking questions publicly or anonymously, receiving announcements and slides, exam info, etc. He allows us to ask questions via this platform in lessons.
reviews.comment_grading:
Mr. Kawaguchi's exams are all closed-book and no cheat sheets are allowed. More effort may be needed to remember the formulas but his papers are at an acceptable level of difficulty and are relatively easier than other professors.

Absolute grading is used. The following is copied from the syllabus on Canvas.
1. Approximately A range for >= 90, B range for >= 80, and C range for >= 50.
2. Midterm 30%: There are two quizzes. The exams are cumulative, but the first exam mainly tests
Part I (15%) and the second exam mainly tests Part II (15%), respectively. The questions in the exam
include both multiple-choice and discussions. The questions do not ask how to use excel. The exams
are closed-book. I provide mock exams and review in the class. The problems are like the end of chapter problems in the textbook.
3. Final Exam 40%: The exam is cumulative but mainly covers Part III. The questions in the final exam
include both multiple-choice and discussions. The questions do not ask how to use excel. The exams
are closed-book. I provide the mock exam and review in the class. The problems are like the end of
chapter problems in the textbook.
4. Assignments 30%: I assign one exercise per chapter. The main purpose of the assignments is to
assess whether the students understand the concepts and can use excel to solve problems. Each
exercise has 5% point. For each student, I give scores based on the best 6 submissions if you submit more than 6 assignments. The deadline will be 1 week for each exercise.
reviews.comment_workload:
There is one assignment for every chapter (19 in total for my semester). Only the 6 assignments with the highest scores will be counted and used to calculate the homework score. The assignments are not compulsory so you can choose not to do them if you already got the full score. The earliest assignments are very simple Excel exercises about making charts and graphs with demonstration videos to follow, so full marks for the 30% assignment score can be easily claimed.

The only shortcoming is that the skills of the earliest assignments (especially Excel-based ones) are not relevant to the course at all.

reviews.author: eri
reviews.comment_content:
Basic knowledge of statistics, which is interesting.

Syllabus:
- Data and variation.
- Time series data.
- Transform data.
- Probability and its rules.
- Tools for organizing probability.
- Probability models.
- Variance and volatility of investments.
- Association and dependence.
- Covariance and portfolio.
- Normal probability distribution.
- Sampling.
- Sampling distributions.
- Standard errors and confidence intervals.
- Statistical hypothesis testing.
- Fitting equation to data.
- The simple regression model. ( Everything learned before is preparing you to delve into this course's most important part!! Regression is used to do forecasting!)
- Inference about SRM
- Introduction to multiple regression.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof HU is sooooo nice!!!
Yvonne is very responsible as well!

Prof HU preceded his lecture with some real-life examples, and told us how to apply the statistical method in reality at the end of the lecture, which makes the content clear and helps us understand the materials better. He and TA reply to emails very quickly and they also hold some extra Q&A sessions if some students need.
reviews.comment_grading:
Fair.

Grading system:
Attendance: 5%
Assignment: 15%
Exams: 80%

Method 1: midterm1*20%+midterm2*20%+final*40%
Method 2: midterm1*5%+midterm2*25%+final*50%
Take the higher of the two.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload are relatively small, just a few group assignments (which will be easy if you take the tutorial), a midterm, and a final exam.

reviews.author: Ada Kwok
reviews.title: Isom 2010 review
reviews.comment_content: covered probability, confidence interval, regression, data, random variables, etc
reviews.comment_teaching:
The prof is so funny and willing to explain concepts after class.

One class he treated the whole class m & m to teach a statistical sampling method.

Overall very interesting and enjoyable lesson.
reviews.comment_grading: Grading is appropriate. Midterm and final are just MC. And the prof provided past paper for practice.
reviews.comment_workload:
Workload is fine. But for students who Is not so good at maths, it do takes time too clear concepts and do past paper for multiple times before exams.

No group projects

reviews.author: MH army
reviews.title: Useful but challenging in later topics
reviews.comment_content:
Topic 1 Data description  
• -  Recognizing the type of data  
• -  Using graphs to see the characteristics of data  
• -  Summarizing messy data into neat numbers  

Topic 2 Probability  
• -  Probability  
• -  Random variable, distributions

Topic 3 Random variables
• -  Discrete random variables: Bernoulli, Binomial distribution  
• -  Continuous random variables: Uniform, normal distribution, t-distribution

Topic 4 Estimation  
• -  Point estimate, Sampling distribution
• -  Confidence intervals
   
Topic 5 Hypothesis testing  
• -  One sample, statistically significant?  
• -  Errors of statistical testing: Type I and Type II errors  
• -  Two independent samples significantly different?  
• -  Examining relationships for nominal and ordinal data  

Topic 6 Simple Linear regression
• -  Basic concept
• -  Checking model assumption
• -  Prediction and estimation

The early topics are about basic probability with later topics being significantly more challenging. A math background is helpful as some calculations are needed. The course serves as a basis for 3000 level statistics courses.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor is friendly and patient, she  explains concepts orderly in class and is willing to help out students and answer questions. There is a break in the middle of the lecture. The slides are neat and easy to understand. There is also zoom recording for later revision, which is especially useful before quizzes and exam.
reviews.comment_grading:
Quiz 1 20%
Quiz 2 20%
4 Group HW 12%
Class participation 3%
Final exam 45%
Quizzes and exam are mc only, quizzes test your knowledge on that section, final exam is cumulative. The cut off can be close, so try to avoid mistakes in quizzes and exam.
reviews.comment_workload: This course is quite time consuming and requires studying and practicing every week to avoid falling behind the class. If you miss a lecture, you should catch up quickly. Group HW serves as practice, you can split the work with teammates and cross check afterwards, if you have teammates good at statistics, they can carry the entire team.

reviews.comment_teaching: I think Prof.Hu is a really good teacher.He is patient and humorous and likes using our day-to-day examples to explain statistical concepts.It's interesting and easy to understand.
reviews.comment_grading: I think the grade is fair but a little bit competitive.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is moderate.We have two group assignments and use Excel as a tool.If you pay attention to the tutorials, that should be fine.

reviews.title: hard work pays off
reviews.comment_content:
Topic 1 Data description  
-Recognizing the type of data
-Using graphs to see the characteristics of data
-Summarizing messy data into neat numbers
Topic 2 Probability  
-Probability
-Random variable, distribution
-Discrete random variables: binomial distribution  
-Continuous random variables: normal distribution, t distribution Topic 3 Estimation

-Confidence intervals

The content in lecture notes might be a bit messy and all over the place. It might help to make your own little notes.
reviews.comment_teaching:
A very passionate and patient instructor.
Sometimes she might teach a bit too fast, so reviewing and previewing material before lecture definitely help. Also, do stay behind and ask her any questions you have, don't be shy, she won't bite.
reviews.comment_grading:
Fair.
Hard work pays off.

Overall percentage: around 92%
Final grading: A+
reviews.comment_workload:
The quizzes, and assignments are not hard. She provides weekly exercises with answers for you. The exercises are helpful with the quizzes and the assignments. You might also need to attend lab sessions in order to do some of the questions in the assignments.

Final is okay if you fully understand the assignments and the exercises. Similar stuff.

The content of Quiz 1, quiz 2 and final do not overlap.

reviews.author: Kellsying
reviews.comment_content: The content is quite practical and mainly about calculation. The ppt is clear and understandable. You can really learn something from this course.
reviews.comment_teaching: Lucy is one of the best professor I have met in ust so far. She teaches the content clearly and  really helpful for us to understand the concept.  She is also able to answer our questions patiently and willing to provide support to students. She provided us sufficient exercises and also responsive to the questions asked in email or class. If you have any questions just feel free to ask her!
reviews.comment_grading:
Pretty good but need to be careful as the cutoff is pretty close with each others.
Quiz 1:20%
Quiz 2:20%
Final exam:45%
Homeworks: 12% (3%×4)
Participation: 3% (absent in each lesson without any reason will deduct 1 mark)
quiz and final exam are all MC. Try to get full marks in quizzes as there are only 1x questions in each quiz, one question take up considerable proportion and can affect your sub grade.
A-range is highly achievable in this course and Lucy is willing to give students A+. This course deserves you to invest time on it. You don't have to spend a lot time, but need to complete the exercises that provided by Lucy for practicing.
reviews.comment_workload: Pretty low workload. Just a 4 group homeworks and most of them are calculation problems. Each person just need to do 3-4 questions for each homework after separating the works in group. However, you may need to spend more time on checking the answer as the mean for the homeworks are high(around 9x/100), a small mistake can make you below mean.

reviews.author: hkuststudent
reviews.title: Rewarding if you work hard
reviews.comment_content:
Topic 1: Data description
- Recognising types of data
- Using graphs to see the characteristics of data
- Summarizing data into

Topic 2: Probability
- Basic probability rules & Bayes theorem
- Random variables, distribution

Topic 3: Randon variables
- Discrete random variables: Binomial and bernouli distribution
- Continuous random variables: Uniform, normal and t-distribution

Topic 4: Estimation
- Sampling distribution
- Confidence intervals

Topic 5: Confidence intervals
- Statistical significance between once sample or two independent samples
- Type I and type II errors
- Examining relationships for nominal and ordinal data

Topic 6: Simple linear regression
(He only had time to go over the basics of regression in one lecture)

Overall the content isn't too difficult, it's quite straightforward when you can recognize the type of problem it's asking about and apply the correct formulas
reviews.comment_teaching:
He was very passionate and enthusiastic about what he was teaching, keeping a positive atmosphere. You might not understand the content of each lecture immediately, but rewatching the lectures will definitely help you make more sense of it. He often pulls up his whiteboard for further elaboration on the concepts, the things he mentions on the whiteboard are sometimes extra info beyond what you're required to learn in the course. If you reach out for help, he will definitely help you clarify concepts and explain them to you until you get it!

He also teaches at his own pace, so our class was often a sub-chapter or two behind other classes.
reviews.comment_grading:
I think you will get the grade you work for. Although the mean was quite high for both quizzes and the final. Here's the weighting for each component:
Quiz 1 - 20%
Quiz 2 - 20%
Group Assignments - 10%
Final - 40%
Attendance - 10% (don't know how this was calculated since it was never released, I think they do take your attendance though)

CLASS STATISTICS:
Quiz 1: 7.9/10 (SD 1.21)
Quiz 2: 7.6/10 (SD 1.89)
Assignment 1: 11.3/13
Assignment 2: 13.1/14
Assignment 3: 22.8/26
Final: 16/20  (SD 2.67)

Both quizzes and final were open book

Quizes were quite straight forward, pay attention in class and he'll give hints on a few questions he's gonna ask in the quiz!

The final exam wasn't too hard, there was a mixture of calculations and conceptual questions - for these know the purpose of each statistical tool and why it's used in a particular context. The level of difficulty of the final was slightly harder than the quizzes.

Final Grade: A
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload wasn't too high, you just need to rewatch all the lectures and take note of + be familiar with all the examples shown in the ppts as those will help you put the concepts into practice. Some questions that came up in the quiz/final were very similar to the ppt examples!

If you want an extra resource to understand the materials, jbstatistics on youtube was very helpful as their videos were concise and had examples!!! The textbook was somewhat useful, but it was quite lengthy so I watched videos instead.

There were also 2 tutorials, attendance wasn't recorded here. Tutorials mainly focused on using excel to solve problems related to the assignments.

想喺度多謝Lucy：
1. 堂上encourage我地試做題目 chatbox每個人問嘅問題一定會詳細答（就算有人on9問題佢都會盡力應）

咁當然，用英文教書的確係難啲 有陣時例如教confidence level嘅時候會頗混亂 但你之後跟著slides自己寫下notes就明白架喇

reviews.comment_content:
Fundamental statistics stuff
I would say they are still very useful because you will apply those concepts again in different business-related subjects (eg: cost accounting, operation management)

reviews.author: L_sbm
reviews.comment_content: Basic statistics topics with business applications composed of 4 parts: 1) Data and Variation 2) Probability 3) Inference 4) Regression. Being familiar with statistics from high school helps.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof. Hu is very kind in answering our questions in class. He often set aside time for questions. He also explains concepts well using words and concepts more familiar to us.

The TA was very nice also. She responds to emails quickly and taught us well during the two tutorials. Her revision/QnA sessions before every exam was helpful.
reviews.comment_grading:
Two schemes, take maximum:
mid1*20%+mid2*20%+final*40%
mid1*5%+mid2*25%+final*50%
(+assignment15%+attendance5%)

I think grading is just okay. You get what you worked for. My midterm and final exam scores were always around mean and I got B range so I guess it's fair. Practicing the sample questions given before exams is very important as most questions are similar.
reviews.comment_workload: Workload is just average. Only need to revise for 2 midterms and 1 final, plus 3 group assignments. Assignments are based on class and tutorial content using excel.

reviews.author: BITBIT
reviews.title: Not bad
reviews.comment_content: This course will expand the statistical knowledge you learned in high school. You will feel like 'so this is how statistics can be used in the stock market/ business!"
reviews.comment_teaching:
He is very passionate and friendly. You can consider him as the 大哥 next door. He is willing to take any question in your mind. However, it is a little fast-paced so do make sure to utilize his personal office hour. He will explain to his best capability.

Many students including myself struggled first understanding his accent at first. However, this became less apparent over time because YOU WILL GET USED IT haha. It sounds better and better over time.

Also a tip... he really likes it if you turn on the Zoom camera because "he doesn't feel like he is talking to a wall" Making a good impression/ asking various questions in class can result in a better grade ;)
reviews.comment_grading:
Final exam's difficulty can be excruciating compared to the preparatory questions he gives prior to the exam. I personally thought I understood the concepts well as I understood all the prep questions. However, I got 25/40 with mean at 23.
So do more questions if you want to make sure you have higher grade.
I got A- at the end.
reviews.comment_workload: If you learned statistics in high school, you will make it to the end. However, if you had not, you must study  A LOT after class.

reviews.author: Harroop
reviews.comment_content: Content was actually pretty interesting : about statistics and how its used and what kind of mistakes can happen by misunderstanding statistics. It was presented with fun examples and the professor made it easy to understand. Highly recommend attending lectures for this one. Sometimes, it may get boring but it'll help during quizzes
reviews.comment_teaching: Although his accent takes a little getting used to, he's actually a pretty great professor who seemed very interested in the course material he taught. I liked his energy, and he would often chill and joke in the class.

Also, screw what other people say/think : I highly encourage you to participate in this course when the professor asks questions: it's actually quite fun and you'll get free grades out of it! Prof Hu will tell you the results of these calculations which are not important and you job is only to remember these results. and understand them.

reviews.author: bcccccc123
reviews.title: Unexpectedly not very bad grade
reviews.comment_content:
business statistics, just similar to DSE M1 syllabus.

4% participation (randomly pick 5 classes, if u attend at least 4 out of 5, you'll get 4%)
HW 1 5%
HW 2 5%
HW 3 6%
20% 1st midterm quiz (20 mc in 1 hour)
20% 2nd midterm quiz (20 mc in 1 hour)
40% Final (40 mc in 2 hours)

A good thing is that there is no overlapping of syllabus in 1st and 2nd midterms and final. It is not accumulated so you don't have to revise the stuff again.

The bad thing is that all midterms and final are in mc format and you can't go back to the previous question once you proceed to the next question,1 question in a time which examines your time management as well, but you never know the coming questions are harder or easier as it is randomly distributed, very harsh. Some questions are like part abcde so if you don't know the first one then probably you'll screw up in the remaining questions. And it may based on the first part (i.e finding the mean) and the next question will be something related to the mean as well.

Another thing is that the question types appeared in Practice Qs and Sample Qs are totally different from the one you see in the midterms and finals.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Many comments claim that Prof. Du's accent was bad, but I think it was still acceptable, but still have times may not understand some words. He is so nice and friendly, will give us 5-10 mins break and chat with classmates. He is willing to answer students' questions in class whenever you raise any questions.
Most of the time I don't really understand his teachings as I think the content is quite hard to understand esp in regression models so I get insights from youtube or doing practice and sample Qs.

TA Anson is great, Personally think that Anson is better than Prof Du. He will hold rechecking midterm quiz session and explain what you get wrong in the midterm quiz in Cantonese, you can choose either Zoom or face-to-face meetings.

There will be 2 tutorial sessions about excel functions held by Anson, not mandatory. His accent is not really good.
reviews.comment_grading:
participation 4% (mean 3.6, highest 4, lowest 0)
HW 1 94/100 (mean 93.9, highest 100, lowest 77)
HW 2 91/100 (mean 93, highest 100, lowest 0)
HW 3 88/100 (mean 85.6, highest 98, lowest 0)
midterm 1 13/20 (mean 13.9, highest 20, lowest 0)
midterm 2 14/20 (mean 14.6, highest 20, lowest 0)
final 15/40 (mean 23.1, highest 39, lowest 0)
Many students claim that the final is very difficult. I agreed and quite a lot of questions consist of different parts and I screw up those from the beginning so I guess I got them all wrong (all parts) .

Final score 60.53/100 (mean 69.6, highest 98.4, lowest 5)
Got C+ at last.
I thought I will get like a C- or D so it is kinda unexpected.
reviews.comment_workload: 3 HW assignment and 2 midterms and 1 final. No stress at all.

reviews.author: Rigbones
reviews.title: Excellent teaching, but insanely high mean
reviews.comment_content:
Has some DSE M1 content and AP statistics content.
You can do well in this course even without any prior statistics knowledge.

Lect 1 introduction
Lect 2 bar charts, pie charts, mode, median, contingency tables
Lect 3 Mosaic plots, histograms, mean, variance, sd, quantiles, whisker box plot
Lect 4 sample covariance, sample correlation, scatterplots
Lect 5 probability
Lect 6 multiplication rule for conditional probability, independence of events, tree diagrams
Lect 7 random variables
Lect 8 joint probability distribution, sums of random variables
Lect 9 class activity
Lect 10 normal random variable, central limit theorem, standardizing (standard score), empirical rule
Lect 11 value at risk (VaR), skewness, kurtosis
Lect 12 sampling, class activity
Lect 13 class activity, sampling distribution, confidence intervals
Lect 14 more confidence intervals, margin of errors
Lect 15 hypothesis testing
Lect 16 least-squares regression line, residuals
Lect 17 reciprocal and natural log transformations
Lect 18 simple regression model, inference about slope and intercept
Lect 19 Prediction intervals
Lect 20 dependent errors
reviews.comment_teaching:
He has a strong accent, it'll be difficult to understand what he says at first, but after 3 or 4 lectures you'll get the hang of it and his accent won't be a problem.  I would not recommend swapping him for another professor solely because of his accent.

Good, precise, and well-focused teaching.  Clearly indicates what is required in the tests and what is not.  Examples in lecture notes highly relevant to those in quizzes and exams.  Does not dive deep into the math behind the formulas, making it easy for first-time learners.

DO NOT SKIP LECTURES.
reviews.comment_grading:
10% class participation
10% homework
45% quizzes 1 and 2
35% final exam

Class participation is 6 marks for answering or raising questions (1 mark per question), and 4 marks for not disrupting classes.

2 quizzes + 1 final exam, all MC.  Before each quiz and exam he will give out a practice quiz, all MC.  The practice quiz is extremely extremely important as the questions are VERY similar to actual quiz/ exam questions.  Make sure you COMPLETELY understand all questions in the practice quizzes.

Homework is some chosen multiple choice questions from the practice quizzes.  Explain why you chose that MC answer.  Total of 3 homework.

Quizzes and exams knowledge is NOT cumulative.  Content tested in quiz 1 will not appear in quiz 2, content tested in quiz 2 will not appear in finals.  Of course some basic concepts like mean, standard deviation are cumulative though.

My grades:
Participation 10/10
Homework 10/10, mean around 8 (I forgot)
Quiz 1 23/23, mean 19.2, sd 2.2
Quiz 2  22/22, mean 18.2, sd 2.6
Finals 34/35, mean 28.5, sd 4.1
Letter grade A+.

Tips for getting A:
watch khan academy videos when there are topics u don't understand.  I took M2 so I have no prior stat knowledge but khan academy helped.  Also never skip classes.  One MC can mean a different final letter grade, so make sure you fully understand the practice quizzes.  Start studying 1 week before the quiz.
reviews.comment_workload: Extremely light.  The 3 homework can be finished in at most an hour.  There are 2 quizzes but start studying one week before the quiz and you'll be fine.

reviews.author: ustspace user
reviews.comment_content:
The same as other reviews of 2019-20 Spring

It is just simple maths and some basic statistical concepts. Not hard if you try to understand it.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Lecturer: XIA, Lucy
The best lecturer I have met in UST so far!

Super nice
Super patient when answering questions both in lectures and email. She will try different approaches to explain until you understand it.

High proficiency of spoken English
Her English is pretty close to native (maybe she is native, idk). Totally understandable.

High ability of explaining concept

Perfectly-organized and well-written ppt
the ppts are rich in content and explanation yet simple and clear. You don't need the textbook if you have her ppts

Highly organized and valuable lectures
Opening a new topic, she follows this flow:
1. begins by briefly capturing the whole idea and structure of the topic
2. in-depth explanation of concept
3. clear, step by step answering approach: if you follow her approaches of answering questions, you will get full mark
4. review of the content taught in the last lesson at the beginning of every lectures. It really helps consolidate your understanding and memory of the contents if you follow through the review

Systematic practice resources
The format of the 4 homeworks is the same as the 2 quizzes and final exam. Before each quiz and exam, she uploads a practice quiz or exam. So in total, you could say there are 7 sets of whole paper to practice. If you do all these, check the answers and understand your mistake, you will definitely do well in the quizzes and exam

I regret not filling the official lecturer evaluation at the end of the semester. The tremendous effort of Lucy should be well-promoted and acknowledged. If you enrolled her classes and agreed, please do so!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

TA: Deng, Stacy
Overall very good TA as well

Very nice
She answers your emails very patiently even after many rounds of follow-up questions. She genuinely wants you to understand the materials.

Coherent paper setting and high quality material
She is the one who sets the HWs, quizzes and exam. They are all so coherent in terms of format, which makes them really good for practice.

Good written English but comparatively weak spoken English
When she writes email, her English is good that she is able to explain concepts in a clear manner. But during tutorials where she needs to speak impromptuly, it takes her some time to process her words and the explanation is not good. But the tutorials cover answering approaches that are also covered in Lucy's lectures, so you may attend tutorials only if you find it hard to follow Lucy's lectures or ppts.
reviews.comment_grading:

HW 3 - 95/100 (Mean=94.4, High=100)
HW 4 - 100/100 (Mean=96.2, High=100)

Final grade = A
